block.p: FED MEETS, AND STOCKS RISE The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the 17th time in a row, but kicked off a celebration in the stock market by lowering its alarms about inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.2 percent -- its biggest one-day gain in almost three years. The other major benchmarks also rose 2 percent or more. [Pages A1 and C1.]

QUESTIONS ON APPLE OPTIONS Apple Computer said that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded from 1997 to 2001, raising questions about whether a large grant made to the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, was properly disclosed. [C1.]

SCRUSHY FOUND GUILTY After twice telling a judge they were deadlocked, a federal jury convicted Donald E. Siegelman, the former Alabama governor, and Richard M. Scrushy, left, the former head of the HealthSouth Corporation, on charges that they conspired in a bribery scheme seven years ago. Lawyers for both men said they would appeal, and both remained free on bond. A year ago, a Birmingham jury acquitted Mr. Scrushy on all charges that he participated in accounting fraud at HealthSouth. [A14.]

ANTI-EMISSIONs EXPERIMENT An experiment by Royal Dutch Shell in the Netherlands to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas blamed for climate change, illustrates a fundamental shift in the oil industry that offers glimmers of hope for the future. [C1.]

U.S. AUTOMAKERS TRY NEW TACK Detroit auto companies, which have lagged behind their Japanese rivals in selling hybrid vehicles, are taking a new environmental direction, by focusing on flexible-fuel vehicles, which can run on gasoline and another type of fuel like ethanol. [C1.]
HOUSE APPROVES OIL DRILLING The House voted to approve oil and gas exploration in coastal waters that have been protected from drilling for 25 years. [A19.]

THE GRAYING OF CHINA By 2020 about a third of Shanghai's population, currently 13.6 million, will consist of people over the age of 59, remaking the city's social fabric and placing huge new strains on its economy and finances. Experts say the rapidly graying city is leading one of the greatest demographic changes in history, one with profound implications for all of China. [A1.]

CERVICAL CANCER VACCINE A federal advisory panel voted unanimously to recommend that all girls and women ages 11 to 26 receive a new vaccine, made by Merck, that prevents most cases of cervical cancer. [A12.]

SHIFT IN KPMG CASE Defendants in the government's mammoth tax-shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG are quietly embracing separate defense strategies, a shift that could reshape the case. [C3.]

BOEING TO TAKE QUARTERLY CHARGE Boeing said that it would take second-quarter charges of up to $1.15 billion as a result of a settlement of ethics investigations with the federal government and delays in surveillance aircraft program for Australia and Turkey. [C3.]
WAL-MART STRIKE AVERTED Wal-Mart's British arm narrowly averted a costly strike after reaching an agreement with a union. [C3.]

TURKEY, EMERGING AND VOLATILE Turkey has suffered a plunge in its bonds and equities, a sign of how a star of emerging markets can quickly become a pariah as billions head for the door. Market Place. [C1.]
JAPAN BOND TRADING HALTS A computer error crippled trading in Japan's government bond market for more than two hours, just months after the Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered a run of similar flaws. [C8.]

TENET SETTLEMENT Tenet Healthcare has reached a $900 million settlement with federal officials to end investigations into accusations of overbilling of Medicare. The settlement -- valued at about one-fourth of Tenet's market value -- will be paid over four years and ends all investigations by the Department of Justice and several United States attorneys, the company said. The company also plans to sell about a dozen hospitals to regain its financial footing. [C3.]

OLD CHEVY ADS, RENEWED Chevrolet is reviving and updating a popular 1970's advertising campaign featuring the musical theme ''Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]

A FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY JUDGE, Allan Gropper, said that Northwest Airlines could throw out its union contract with flight attendants if two more weeks of talks did not produce a deal. (AP)
BAXTER INTERNATIONAL, the maker of blood-disease treatments, said federal regulators agreed to consider allowing the company to resume sales of medical pumps tied to two deaths. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

SHARES OF AVENTINE Renewable Energy Holdings, the large ethanol producer, fell 10.8 percent in their first day of trading after the company increased the sale price and sold more shares. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
